body.p: To his Excellency, Thomas E. Bramlette, Governor of Kentucky.

The petition of Charles Eaves and M. D. Hay, of Muhlenberg County, Kentucky, who respectfully show to your Excellency.- That a judgment was rendered against them in the Muhlenberg Circuit Court, on the 13th day of May, 1861, on favor of the Commonwealth, for two hundred dollars, & costs, on forfeited recognizance, entered into by them in said Court, as the bail of Edward Hartman, on the 14th day of November 1860 on the 16th day of May, 1860, for the appearance of said Hartman in said Court on the second day of its next term, to answer an Indictment against him for permitting gaming in his house. That said Hartman failed to appear at the next term, having left the State, without the knowledge of your any connivance on the part of your petitioners. That said Hartman at the date of said recognizance resided in the town of Greenville, Ky, and pledged his word to your petitioners not to leave the state, and to appear in discharge of his recognizance at the next term of the court. That your petitioners have received information, which they believe to be true, that said Hartman removed to the State of Missouri ^Iowa^, and there enlisted as a soldier in the volunteer service of the United States, and was killed in battle at the battle of Wilsons creek ^Shilo^. That said prosecution against Hartman has been tried. Wherefore, as your petitioners are poor and have families to support, they respectfully ask your Excellency to remit said Judgment on said forfeited recognizance
Sworn to before me by Charles Eaves & M D. Hay this 15th day of March 1864.
Geo Dyer M P M C

The undersigned members of the bar and officers of the Muhlenberg Circuit Court, endorse the statements of the foregoing petition of Charles Eaves and M. D. Hay as true, and concur in the prayer thereof and respectfully ask the remission of said judgment
